title: 111_hr6207
content: The "Rural Flood Mitigation and Recovery Act of 2010" allows the Secretary of the Army to recommend flood damage reduction projects based on the non-Federal interest's demonstration of the project's necessity for long-term economic viability in flood prone disaster areas. SEC. 428 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act addresses flood prone disaster areas by amending Title IV and adding new provisions. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, specifically in section 428, addresses flood prone disaster areas by determining if an area qualifies based on experiencing at least 2 other major disasters due to flooding in the 5-year period preceding the declaration of a major disaster. This determination applies to assistance provided under the Act for that disaster. In flood prone disaster areas, the President can increase federal contributions for hazard mitigation measures to 90% or 100% if necessary for long-term economic viability. In flood prone disaster areas, the President can increase federal contributions for hazard mitigation measures to 20% or 25%, and for repair and restoration of facilities to 90%. In flood prone disaster areas, the President can increase federal contributions for hazard mitigation measures to 20% or 25%, and for repair and restoration of facilities to 90%. Additionally, task forces are established in each State to coordinate response activities for major disasters in the area, composed of relevant Federal and State agency heads. SEC. 4. HAZARD MITIGATION. Amends Section 404 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to specify timing requirements for contributions to hazard mitigation measures after a major disaster is declared. SEC. 5. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO INDIVIDUALS AND HOUSEHOLDS. SEC. 5 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to consider economic impact and previous disasters when providing assistance to individuals and households affected by a major disaster. SEC. 6 amends Section 120(e) of title 23, United States Code, allowing for extended time for completion of projects due to inclement weather or flooding. SEC. 7 establishes a pilot program for the repair, restoration, and replacement of damaged facilities. During a 2-year period, the President will select 3 major disasters for modified response procedures. This involves making contributions for repair projects based on selected bids. A report is required within 30 months of enactment. The President will submit a report to Congress within 30 months of enacting the Act, detailing the outcomes of using modified response procedures, including benefits and overpayments. SEC. 8. INDIAN TRIBE DISASTER RESPONSE MANAGEMENT PILOT PROGRAM. The President will establish an Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program, selecting 5 tribes to participate based on past major disaster declarations on their lands. The Indian tribe disaster response management pilot program allows selected tribes to be treated as states for requesting disaster declarations and managing response activities for a 5-year period. The President can provide technical assistance and grants to Indian tribes selected for the disaster response management program. A report must be submitted to Congress within 30 months of the program's enactment, detailing results and recommendations, including the possibility of making the program permanent for all tribes. The Administrator of FEMA can grant states funds for studying and prioritizing road projects for disaster preparedness. Additionally, a communication report is required. The Administrator of FEMA must submit a report to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment detailing efforts to improve communication with State and local officials regarding disaster response, recovery, and hazard mitigation programs, along with recommendations for further enhancing communication. SEC. 11 of the Act requires the President to submit a report to Congress within 6 months detailing the use of contributions for hazard mitigation projects. It includes an assessment of effectiveness, recommendations for improvement, and the interaction with contributions for hazard mitigation measures under section 404 of the Act. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of disaster relief processes under the Stafford Act in assisting distressed communities, including Indian tribes. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 12 months. Additionally, a study on paperwork reduction for hazard mitigation projects will be conducted. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the application processes and paperwork required for programs under the Stafford Act that provide assistance for hazard mitigation activities. A report with recommendations for streamlining these processes must be submitted to Congress within 12 months.
